__Valence__  __ __  __electrons__  __ __ are those  electrons that occupy the  outer shell\.

Examples  of conductors:   <span style="color:#ff0000">G</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">o</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">ld\,</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">Si</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">l</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">ve</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">r</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">\,</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">Aluminum</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">\, Copper\.</span>

<span style="color:#ff0000"> __Copper__ </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> __ __ </span> is an example of an excellent  __conductor__ \.

It has only one electron in its valence band\, which  can easily escape to the conduction band\, leaving  behind a  __positive ion __ \(the core\)\.

# Semiconductors

<span style="color:#c00000"> __Valence__ </span>  <span style="color:#c00000"> __ __ </span>  <span style="color:#c00000"> __electrons:__ </span>  <span style="color:#c00000"> __ __ </span>

There are 4 valence electrons in the outer \(valence\) shell of both  <span style="color:#008000">Silicon</span>  <span style="color:#008000"> </span>  <span style="color:#008000">\(Si\) </span>  <span style="color:#008000">and</span>  <span style="color:#008000"> </span>  <span style="color:#008000">Germanium </span>  <span style="color:#008000">\(Ge\)\.</span>

![](l1-semiconductors-img/l1-semiconductors_5.jpg)

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

![](l1-semiconductors-img/l1-semiconductors_6.png)

The valence electrons in germanium are in the fourth shell while  those in silicon are in the third shell\,  <span style="color:#ff0000">closer</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">to</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">the</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">nucleus\.</span>

This means that the germanium valence electrons are at  _higher _  _ _  _energy_  _ levels_  _ than_  _ _  _those_  _ in_  _ _  _silicon_  and\, therefore\, require a   <span style="color:#008000">smaller</span>  <span style="color:#008000"> </span>  <span style="color:#008000">amount</span>  <span style="color:#008000"> </span>  <span style="color:#008000">of</span>  <span style="color:#008000"> </span>  <span style="color:#008000">additional</span>  <span style="color:#008000"> </span>  <span style="color:#008000">energy</span>  <span style="color:#008000"> </span>  <span style="color:#008000">to</span>  <span style="color:#008000"> </span>  <span style="color:#008000">escape</span>  <span style="color:#008000"> </span>  <span style="color:#008000">from</span>  <span style="color:#008000"> </span>  <span style="color:#008000">the</span>  <span style="color:#008000"> </span>  <span style="color:#008000">atom</span> \.

Feature that makes germanium more unstable at high temperature\.

Hence the popularity of silicon\-based semiconductors\.

![](l1-semiconductors-img/l1-semiconductors_7.png)

<span style="color:#0000ff">Note: In a </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">silicon crystal\, there are billions of silicon atoms\, each </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">with eight </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">valence electrons\.</span>

::: {.notes}

:::

![](l1-semiconductors-img/l1-semiconductors_8.png)

<span style="color:#c00000"> __Covalent__ </span>  <span style="color:#c00000"> __ Bonds:__ </span>  <span style="color:#c00000"> __ __ </span>

![](l1-semiconductors-img/l1-semiconductors_9.png)

Unlike metals\, silicon forms strong  <span style="color:#0000ff"> __covalent bonds __ </span> \(shared electrons\) with its neighboring atoms making a crystalline structure\.

A silicon atom with its  four valence electrons  shares an electron with  each of its four  neighbours\.

![](l1-semiconductors-img/l1-semiconductors_10.png)

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

![](l1-semiconductors-img/l1-semiconductors_11.png)

This effectively creates   <span style="color:#ff0000">eight valence electrons  for each atom </span> and  produces a state of   <span style="color:#008000">chemical stability</span>  <span style="color:#008000">\.</span>

When the valence orbit has  <span style="color:#0000ff">eight electrons\, it is saturated because  no more electrons can fit into this orbit\.</span>

![](l1-semiconductors-img/l1-semiconductors_12.png)

<span style="color:#0000ff">Intrinsic silicon is a poor conductor </span> because most of the electrons are bound in the crystal and take part in forming the bonds between atoms\.

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

A semiconductor is different from an insulator because at any temperature above absolute zero temperature\,  there is a small number of electrons in the lattice which will  become loose from their atoms\, leaving behind an  empty space called a  <span style="color:#0000ff">"hole"\.</span>

In  <span style="color:#0000ff">intrinsic</span>  \(“pure”\) silicon\, a few electrons can jump the energy gap between the valence and conduction band\. Having moved into the conduction band\, a "hole" is left in the crystal structure\.

![](l1-semiconductors-img/l1-semiconductors_13.jpg)

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

<span style="color:#c00000">The </span>  <span style="color:#c00000">current which will flow </span>  <span style="color:#c00000">in an </span>  <span style="color:#c00000">intrinsic  semiconductor consists </span>  <span style="color:#c00000">of both </span>  <span style="color:#c00000">electron </span>  <span style="color:#c00000">and hole  current</span> \.

The conduction band electrons are free to move under the influence of an electric field\. \(“ <span style="color:#0000ff">electron current</span> ”\)

The bound \(valence\) electrons move between atoms\, effectively moving “holes” from one atom to another as illustrated\. Holes act like positive charges\, with their own mobility\. \(“ <span style="color:#0000ff">hole current</span> ”\)

![](l1-semiconductors-img/l1-semiconductors_14.png)

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

<span style="color:#0000ff">Electric current </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">in the </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">conductor </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> _decreases_ </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> with the  increase in</span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">temperature\.</span>

<span style="color:#ff0000">Increase in the </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">temperature increases the vibration </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">of  </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">atoms\.</span>

<span style="color:#ff0000">These vibrating atoms </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">oppose the </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">flow </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">of  </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">electrons</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">\.</span>

<span style="color:#6f2f9f">Vibrating </span>  <span style="color:#6f2f9f">atoms </span>  <span style="color:#6f2f9f">in the </span>  <span style="color:#6f2f9f">semiconductor </span>  <span style="color:#6f2f9f">oppose only </span>  <span style="color:#6f2f9f">few  electrons and </span>  <span style="color:#6f2f9f">the </span>  <span style="color:#6f2f9f">remaining </span>  <span style="color:#6f2f9f">large </span>  <span style="color:#6f2f9f">number of electrons  flows </span>  <span style="color:#6f2f9f">freely from one </span>  <span style="color:#6f2f9f">place </span>  <span style="color:#6f2f9f">to </span>  <span style="color:#6f2f9f">another place</span>  <span style="color:#6f2f9f">\.</span>

# Extrinsic Materials



* Since semiconductors are generally poor conductors\, their conductivity can be drastically increased by the controlled addition of impurities to the intrinsic \(pure\) semi\-conductive material\. This process\, called  <span style="color:#0000ff">doping</span> \.
* A semiconductor material that has been subjected to doping is called an  <span style="color:#c00000"> __extrinsic__ </span>  <span style="color:#c00000"> __ __ </span>  <span style="color:#c00000"> __material__ </span>  <span style="color:#c00000"> __\.__ </span>
  * Two types;
    * <span style="color:#0000ff"> __n\-type__ </span>
    * <span style="color:#0000ff"> __p\-type__ </span>
* __n\-type	__  __material__  __:__
  * <span style="color:#0000ff">Created by introducing </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">impurity atoms </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">\(doping\) that have </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> _5 valence _ </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> _electrons_ </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> _ _ </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">\(pentavalent\)</span>
::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

![](l1-semiconductors-img/l1-semiconductors_16.png)

This allows  <span style="color:#ff0000">four</span>  out of the  <span style="color:#ff0000">five</span>  orbital electrons bonds with its neighboring silicon  atoms leaving one  _“free _  _electron” _ to become mobile when an electrical voltage is  applied \(electron flow\)\.

As each impurity atom “donates” one electron\,  _pentavalent_   atoms are generally known as  <span style="color:#ff0000">“</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> __donors__ </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">”\.</span>

<span style="color:#0000ff"> _The resulting _ </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> _semiconductor _ </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> _basics _ </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> _material _ </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> _has _ </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> _an_ </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> _ _ </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> _excess_ </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> _ _ </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> _of current\-carrying electrons\, each with a negative_ </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> _ _ </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> _charge_ </span>

<span style="color:#0000ff"> _Sb: antimony_ </span>

![](l1-semiconductors-img/l1-semiconductors_17.png)

__N\-type __ material electrons is called  “Majority Carriers” while the resulting  holes are called “Minority Carriers”\.

<span style="color:#c00000">Majority and Minority Carriers\.</span>

In an  <span style="color:#ff0000"> _n\-type_ </span>  material the electron is called the majority carrier and the hole the  minority carrier\.

In a  <span style="color:#ff0000"> _p\-type_ </span>  material the hole is called the majority carrier and the electron the minority carrier\.

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

# PN Junction

A p\- and an n\-material together form a PN junction\.

When the junction is formed\, conduction electrons move to the p\- region\, and fall into holes\. Filling a hole makes a negative ion and leaves behind a positive ion in the n\-region\.

This creates a thin region \( <span style="color:#3366ff">Depletion Region</span> \) that is depleted of free charges at the boundary  <span style="color:#ff0000">which prevents further charge migration\.</span>
